book.title: My First Novel
book.description: A guided starter project following Paige as she learns to write her first novel using StoryLab—complete with tutorials, tips, and a little meta-fiction magic.

parts.title: Part I – The Day I Finally Start
parts.notes: Paige discovers the core features: manuscript, outline, corkboard, and grid.

parts.title: Part II – Seeing the Story
parts.notes: Paige explores deeper analytical tools and commits to the long game of drafting.

chapters.title: Alarm, Coffee, and Good Intentions
chapters.content:
The alarm sang at 6:00 AM with a cheerful reminder Paige had programmed three months ago: "Write the Damn Book." She groaned, silenced it, and padded to the kitchen where Comma the Cat was already judging her from atop the fridge. Coffee first. Then courage.

By 6:47, she sat at her desk, mug steaming, and opened StoryLab. The project glowed at her: My First Novel. The manuscript pane stretched blank and infinite, cursor blinking with quiet menace. Paige cracked her knuckles. Today was the day. Probably.
chapters.outline:
• Paige wakes to "Write the Damn Book" alarm
  • Makes coffee while Comma judges
  • Opens StoryLab project for the first time in weeks
  • Faces the blank manuscript with a mix of terror and determination
chapters.outlinePurpose: Establish Paige's intention to finally start writing and introduce the StoryLab interface.
chapters.outlineGoal: Paige wants to open the project and feel ready to write, proving to herself that today is different.
chapters.outlineConflict: The blank page is intimidating, and Paige's history of false starts looms over her.
chapters.outlineStakes: If she doesn't start now, the cycle of procrastination continues and the novel never gets written.

chapters.title: The Blank Page Stares Back
chapters.content:
Paige stared at the manuscript. The manuscript stared back. She toggled to the outline pane—also blank. Back to manuscript. Still blank. This was fine. Totally fine.

She typed: "The protagonist walked into the room." Paige grimaced. Weak. Vague. But it was something. She hit enter twice and added: "The room was... a room." Comma hopped onto the desk, tail swishing. Even the cat knew this was bad. But bad words were better than no words, right? Right?
chapters.outline:
• Paige toggles between blank manuscript and outline
  • Writer's block hits hard
  • Types deliberately bad sentences just to break the silence
  • Comma appears and silently judges the prose
  • Paige questions whether bad writing is progress
chapters.outlinePurpose: Show the painful reality of starting: everything feels wrong and clumsy.
chapters.outlineGoal: Write literally anything to prove the blank page doesn't own her.
chapters.outlineConflict: Perfectionism and self-doubt make even simple sentences feel impossible.
chapters.outlineStakes: If she can't push through the awkwardness now, she'll delete it all and quit.

chapters.title: Outlines, Rabbitholes, and Color-Coded Hope
chapters.content:
Paige gave up on the manuscript for now and clicked over to the outline view. Maybe structure would save her. She added bullet points: Opening scene. Introduce conflict. Character wants something. Basic, but visible.

Then she discovered tags. Blue for POV. Amber for subplot threads. Gray for drafts-in-progress. Suddenly the outline wasn't just a list—it was a map. She color-coded her first three chapters, then leaned back. Paige smiled. She could see the structure now, even if the words weren't there yet.
chapters.outline:
• Paige switches to outline view to escape the blank manuscript
  • Adds initial chapter beats and discovers tags
  • Experiments with color-coding chapters by POV and subplot
  • Realizes structure makes the book feel less overwhelming
  • First moment of genuine optimism
chapters.outlinePurpose: Introduce outlining and tagging as tools for creating visible structure.
chapters.outlineGoal: Build a roadmap so the story feels less like chaos and more like a plan.
chapters.outlineConflict: Paige tends to overthink structure and fall into research rabbitholes instead of writing.
chapters.outlineStakes: If she gets lost in planning, she'll never return to drafting real scenes.

chapters.title: Corkboard Chaos (In a Good Way)
chapters.content:
Paige clicked the Corkboard tab and gasped. Cards. Dozens of them, colorful and draggable, each representing a scene or idea. One card read: "Drag me to another chapter." She did. It moved. Magic.

She added a new card: "Scene Idea: Protagonist realizes the truth." Tagged it key-thread. Opened the inspector panel and set the status to todo. Then Comma stepped directly onto the keyboard, and a card titled "jjjjjjjjjjjjj" appeared. Paige laughed, deleted it, and gave Comma a scratch. Chaos, but the fun kind.
chapters.outline:
• Paige discovers the corkboard view with draggable scene cards
  • Experiments with moving cards between chapters
  • Creates new cards and explores the inspector panel
  • Comma walks on keyboard, creating accidental card
  • Paige feels playful and in control of the story's pieces
chapters.outlinePurpose: Introduce the corkboard as a spatial, playful way to organize scenes.
chapters.outlineGoal: Understand how to use scene cards to break down the story into movable, trackable pieces.
chapters.outlineConflict: The sheer possibility of rearranging everything is overwhelming in a new way.
chapters.outlineStakes: If she can't wrangle the corkboard, it becomes just another distraction tool.

chapters.title: Threads, Themes, and Mild Panic
chapters.content:
Paige opened the Grid. Rows for themes. Columns for chapters. Little cells marking where Self-Doubt spiked, where Momentum stalled. One row glowed with a label: Core Story Thread. Seed. Buildup. Event. Aftermath.

She clicked a cell in Chapter 2 and saw her own note: "Self-Doubt intensity: 3." Accurate. Painfully so. But seeing it mapped—visible across chapters—made it feel less like drowning and more like data. She could fix data. Maybe. Comma meowed. Paige exhaled. "Okay. I see you, story. Let's do this."
chapters.outline:
• Paige opens the grid view for the first time
  • Sees themes and a story thread mapped across chapters
  • Notices "Self-Doubt" intensity is highest in early chapters
  • Feels simultaneously panicked and in control
  • Realizes the grid makes invisible patterns visible
chapters.outlinePurpose: Introduce the grid as a tool for visualizing themes and threads across the manuscript.
chapters.outlineGoal: Understand where themes appear and how the core thread develops over time.
chapters.outlineConflict: Seeing her own emotional patterns (Self-Doubt, Momentum) reflected in the grid is uncomfortable.
chapters.outlineStakes: If the grid overwhelms her, she'll close it and lose the chance to see the story structurally.

chapters.title: The First Real Scene
chapters.content:
Paige returned to the manuscript. Armed with outline beats, corkboard cards, and a grid full of intentions, she wrote. Not perfectly. Not even well. But real.

The scene unfolded: her protagonist entering a library, looking for a book that didn't exist. Paige linked the scene to a card on the corkboard, checked it off as draft. She glanced at the outline. Check. She updated the grid cell for Chapter 6. Check. 486 words. Imperfect, fixable, hers. Paige saved the file and felt something she hadn't felt in months: pride.
chapters.outline:
• Paige returns to manuscript, ready to write for real
  • Writes a full scene (protagonist in library)
  • Links scene to corkboard card and marks it as draft
  • Updates grid and outline to reflect progress
  • Sees word count climb and feels unexpected pride
chapters.outlinePurpose: Show the payoff: using structure and tools leads to actual writing.
chapters.outlineGoal: Write a complete, imperfect scene and feel like a real writer.
chapters.outlineConflict: The scene isn't perfect, and Paige has to resist the urge to delete it.
chapters.outlineStakes: If she deletes this, she'll spiral back into perfectionism and never finish a draft.

chapters.title: Future Paige Visits the Grid
chapters.content:
Paige closed her eyes and imagined herself six months from now, scrolling across a fully developed grid. Forty chapters. Eight themes. Story threads weaving through like highways on a map. A bird's-eye view of the entire novel.

She could see which chapters carried the revenge subplot, where the protagonist's arc turned, where foreshadowing bloomed into payoff. Future Paige hovered over a cell and saw notes: "Red herring planted here. Resolve in Ch. 38." Comma meowed, snapping her back to the present. Chapter 6. Twelve to go. But now she could see the destination.
chapters.outline:
• Paige imagines a future version of herself with a complete manuscript
  • Envisions a fully developed grid showing all arcs and motifs
  • Sees the grid as a bird's-eye map of the entire novel
  • Realizes the grid will grow with her as the story develops
  • Snaps back to present but feels motivated
chapters.outlinePurpose: Transition into Part II by showing Paige imagining future, deeper tools.
chapters.outlineGoal: Envision what the completed story will look like in StoryLab's analytical views.
chapters.outlineConflict: The gap between six chapters and forty feels impossibly wide.
chapters.outlineStakes: If she can't hold onto the vision, she'll lose motivation before reaching the middle.

chapters.title: Timeline Dreams
chapters.content:
Paige daydreamed about a timeline slider that didn't exist yet. She imagined dragging it from Chapter 1 to Chapter 40, watching character states shift: Protagonist: hopeful → betrayed → determined. Items gained and lost. Secrets revealed and kept.

She pictured a little icon appearing over Chapter 14: "Necklace acquired." Another at Chapter 29: "Necklace lost." StoryLab tracking every object, every emotional beat. Paige scribbled a note on a corkboard card: "Timeline feature request: Track the damn necklace." Comma knocked a pen off the desk. Paige grinned. "Coming soon," she whispered.
chapters.outline:
• Paige imagines a timeline slider showing character and item states across chapters
  • Envisions tracking emotional arcs and object possession over time
  • Realizes a timeline could reveal continuity gaps
  • Writes a feature request card on the corkboard
  • Frames this as aspirational / "coming soon"
chapters.outlinePurpose: Introduce the idea of a timeline tool for tracking continuity and change.
chapters.outlineGoal: Imagine a tool that could help track complex continuity across many chapters.
chapters.outlineConflict: The tool doesn't exist yet, and Paige must track things manually for now.
chapters.outlineStakes: Without timeline tracking, continuity errors will slip through and weaken the story.

chapters.title: Foreshadow, Payoff, and That One Lost Clue
chapters.content:
Paige squinted at Chapter 2, where her protagonist had found a strange key. She'd almost forgotten about it. If she didn't do something with that key by Chapter 20, readers would riot.

She imagined visual lines connecting setup to payoff: a glowing thread from the key in Chapter 2 to a locked door in Chapter 18. StoryLab showing her every dangling thread, every unresolved question. She opened a corkboard card: "Resolve the key by Ch. 18." Set it to todo, colored it red. Comma blinked slowly. "I know," Paige said. "I almost forgot. But not anymore."
chapters.outline:
• Paige realizes she planted a key in Chapter 2 but hasn't resolved it
  • Imagines visual foreshadow-payoff lines connecting chapters
  • Creates a corkboard reminder to resolve the key by Chapter 18
  • Understands that tracking setups prevents plot holes
  • Feels relieved to have caught the issue early
chapters.outlinePurpose: Show how tracking foreshadowing and payoff prevents loose threads.
chapters.outlineGoal: Identify and plan resolution for an early story element (the key).
chapters.outlineConflict: Paige almost forgot the key entirely; the risk of dropped threads is real.
chapters.outlineStakes: If she forgets to resolve the key, readers will feel cheated and the story loses credibility.

chapters.title: Character Arcs and Emotional Weather
chapters.content:
Paige envisioned character arc graphs: lines rising and falling across chapters, tracking confidence, trust, fear. She imagined clicking on Protagonist and seeing a curve: Self-Doubt peaks at Chapter 11, drops at Chapter 23, rises again at Chapter 35.

Emotional weather. That's what it was. And StoryLab could map the forecast. She opened the grid again, staring at her own Self-Doubt theme row. The intensity climbed through early chapters, dipped at Chapter 6. She laughed. "I'm writing my own arc without realizing it." Comma meowed in agreement. Paige took a screenshot of the grid. Evidence that she was learning.
chapters.outline:
• Paige imagines character evolution graphs showing emotional arcs
  • Envisions tracking protagonist's self-doubt, confidence, fear across chapters
  • Realizes she's been unconsciously writing her own emotional arc into the story
  • Sees the parallel between her struggle and her protagonist's
  • Takes a screenshot of the grid as a milestone
chapters.outlinePurpose: Explore character arc tracking and the meta-parallel between Paige and her protagonist.
chapters.outlineGoal: Understand how emotional arcs develop over time and can be visualized.
chapters.outlineConflict: Paige sees her own self-doubt mirrored in the protagonist and must decide whether to embrace it.
chapters.outlineStakes: If she doesn't track emotional arcs, the story will feel flat and characters won't grow believably.

chapters.title: Heatmaps and Hard Truths
chapters.content:
Paige opened an imaginary heatmap view overlaid on her manuscript. Chapters 1–6 glowed green: Strong start. Chapters 7–9: pale yellow. Sagging middle. Chapters 10–12: bright red. Weak. Fix this.

Instead of panicking, Paige felt... clarity. The heatmap wasn't an insult. It was a revision roadmap. She opened a new corkboard card: "Strengthen Chapters 10–12: Add subplots, raise stakes, connect to thread." Set the status to revision. Paige cracked her knuckles. "Okay. Now I know where to dig."
chapters.outline:
• Paige imagines a heatmap showing chapter strength across the manuscript
  • Sees weak spots in the middle chapters highlighted in red
  • Feels clarity instead of panic: this is actionable data
  • Creates a revision card targeting weak chapters
  • Treats the heatmap as a roadmap, not a judgment
chapters.outlinePurpose: Introduce heatmaps as diagnostic tools for identifying weak structural areas.
chapters.outlineGoal: Use a heatmap to identify and plan revisions for weak chapters.
chapters.outlineConflict: Seeing weaknesses visualized could trigger perfectionism and despair.
chapters.outlineStakes: If Paige can't handle honest feedback (even from herself), she'll never revise effectively.

chapters.title: Hitting Save on Something That Matters
chapters.content:
Paige leaned back in her chair. The manuscript wasn't done. Not even close. But it was started. Six chapters drafted. Twelve planned. A grid full of threads. A corkboard mapped with intentions. She'd learned more in one day than in six months of stalling.

She hit Save. The file updated. Comma purred. Paige stood, stretched, and made a promise to herself: Tomorrow, I'll write Chapter 7. And the day after, Chapter 8. And I'll keep going until this thing is real. She closed her laptop and gave Comma a treat. Today, she'd finally started. Tomorrow, she'd keep building.
chapters.outline:
• Paige reflects on the day's progress: six chapters drafted, twelve outlined

  • Realizes she's learned more by doing than by procrastinating

  • Saves the project and commits to continuing tomorrow

  • Gives Comma a treat as a small celebration

  • Closes laptop with a sense of accomplishment and momentum
chapters.outlinePurpose: Conclude the story with Paige committing to the long-term process of writing.
chapters.outlineGoal: Acknowledge progress, save the work, and commit to showing up tomorrow.
chapters.outlineConflict: The novel is far from finished, and the hardest work is still ahead.
chapters.outlineStakes: If Paige doesn't commit to consistency, this will be just another false start.

characters.name: Comma the Cat
characters.role: Paige's cat and silent accountability buddy
characters.notes: Comma shows up during writing sessions, sits on keyboards, and provides wordless judgment and companionship.

characters.name: Paige
characters.notes: Paige is determined to finally write her first novel. She's smart, self-aware, and battles perfectionism daily.

characters.name: StoryLab
characters.role: The writing app, personified in Paige's imagination
characters.notes: StoryLab is calm, quietly judgmental, but ultimately supportive—a digital muse that reveals structure and insight.

boards.name: My First Novel – Getting Started
boards.description: Tutorial-style cards that demonstrate corkboard features while planning Paige's story.

cards.title: Drag Me to Another Chapter
cards.summary: Try dragging this card to a different chapter to see how corkboard reordering works. It's surprisingly satisfying!

cards.title: Open My Inspector
cards.summary: Click the 'i' icon on this card to edit my status, color, tags, or add detailed notes. Inspector = your friend.

cards.title: Try Tagging Me
cards.summary: Add a tag like 'subplot' or 'thread' and see where it appears across your project. Tags are organizational magic.

cards.title: Scene Idea: Paige's Worst Draft Ever
cards.summary: A messy scene where Paige writes the worst possible version on purpose to break perfectionism. Sometimes bad drafts are the breakthrough.
cards.notes: This could be a flashback or a moment of desperation. Either way, it's liberating.

cards.title: A Clue Paige Forgot to Resolve
cards.summary: Reminder to pay off the key detail introduced in Chapter 2. Don't let it dangle!
cards.notes: The key needs to unlock something by Chapter 18 or readers will throw the book.

cards.title: Revision To-Do: Strengthen Chapter 2
cards.summary: Chapter 2 feels weak. Add more internal conflict, maybe a secondary character to bounce off.
cards.notes: Heatmap flagged this. Trust the data.

cards.title: Part II: Future Features Notes
cards.summary: Use this card to jot down what you'd like StoryLab to reveal about your story in the future: timelines, heatmaps, arc graphs.
cards.notes: Timeline tracking for objects and character states would be incredible.

cards.title: Opening Hook Tutorial
cards.summary: Make sure Chapter 1 grabs attention fast. Start with action, emotion, or a question.

cards.title: Theme Mapping Exercise
cards.summary: Practice using the grid to map where themes appear. Mark presence and intensity.

cards.title: Subplot: Comma's Secret Life
cards.summary: A running joke where Comma judges Paige's writing choices. Adds levity and personality.
cards.notes: Comma is basically a writing coach in feline form.

cards.title: Track the Necklace
cards.summary: Timeline feature request: Track when objects appear, move, and disappear across chapters.
cards.notes: This would solve so many continuity headaches.

cards.title: Character Arc: Paige's Growth
cards.summary: Paige starts perfectionist and blocked, ends trusting iteration and structure. Map this across all 12 chapters.
cards.notes: Parallel to protagonist's arc. Meta-fiction vibes.
